cab.content: THIS DOCUMENT IS, THE PROPERTY OP HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENTPrinted for the War Cabinet. April ,1942.,SECRET Copy No.. ^W.M. (42)44th Conclusions.TO BE KEPT UNDER LOCK AND KEY. *iIt is requested that special care may be taken toensure the secrecy of this document.WAR CABINET 44 (42).CONCESSIONS of a Meeting? of the War Cabinet held at Iff, Downing StreetrS.W. 1, on Wednesday, April 8, 1942, at 12 noose.Present:The Right Hon. Winston S. Churchill, M.P., Prime Minister (in the Chair).The Right Hon. C. R. Attlee, M.P.,Secretary of State for DominionAffairs.The Right Hon. Anthony: Eden, M.P.,Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.The Bight Hon: Sir John Anderson,,M.P., Lord President of the Council.The Right Hon. Oliver Lytteetbn,M.P., Minister of Production.The Rt. Hon. Ernest Bevin, M.P.,Minister of Labour and' NationalService.The following were also present:The Right Hon. Sir archibald sinclair, Bt., M.P., Secretary ofState for Air.Sir Edward Bridges, Secretary.Contents.minute no. Subject. page 1 Prisoners of War ..... .... . ..........'.. 200Exchange of Sick and Wounded with Italy.2 Italy .... ............. .... .... .... .... 200Repatriation of Civilians from Ethiopia.3 Telecommunications Research Establishment, Swanage.... 2004 U.S.S.R....... .... .... .... .... .... .... .... 200[23684] Prisoners ofWar.Exchange ofSick and wounded with italy.Italy.Repatriation of civilians fromEthiopia.(previous reference:W.M. (42) 23rdConclusions,Minute 4.)Tele-;communicationsResearchEstablishment,Swanage.U.S.S.R.(previous reference:W.M. (42) 37thConclusions.)1.- The Foreign, secretary reported to the War Cabinet thatarrangements had been made, and were now' proceeding, for an exchange of sick and wounded prisoners with Italy in theMediterranean.The War Cabinet- .1Approved the action taken by the Foreign Secretary. , ,2. The Foreign Secretary reported that better progress was now being made with the arrangements for the repatriation to italy of Italian civilians from Ethiopia.3. Reference was made to this Establishment. The WarCabinet were informed that the Chiefs of Staff had recommendedthat it should be moved inland.The Prime Minister asked for a report by 6 p.m. that eveningas to the steps taken to provide an adequate guard for this Estab-lishment in the meantime.4. The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theSecretary of State for Foreign Affairs (W.P. (42) 144).The War Cabinet-Approved the action proposed in this Memorandum, and authorised the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs toproceed accordingly.[A record of detailed points made in discussion is contained in the Secretary's Standard File of War cabinet conclusions;]Great George Street, S. W. 1,April 8, 1942.
